Insecure Banking, done the right way.
DIBA was created with the intention of feeling like any other banking app you could find on the playstore, with the key difference being that it is intentionally weak in its security.

In junction with the DIBAServer, it is a training opportunity for mobile penetration testers that contains many android specific weaknesses in varying difficulty. It can furthermore serve as a tool for educators, who want to create a curriculum for their students.

Most if not all parts of the app are attackable in some way, shape or form. While some vulnerabilities might be exploitable from within the app, others need you to use tools or even write your own malicious app.

Run an instance of the DIBAServer on your PC, as long as it has internet connectivity you should be fine. Be aware that if your cellphone and server are not in the same network, you might have to port forward the port 8443 for it to work. Now you must fetch the ip address of your server with ifconfig (or simmilar) and adjust IP in the metasettings of DIBA.

While the communication between the client (app) and server are not the main focus of DIBAs security, you can adjust the difficulty level of the communication security to test your knowledge in ssl/tls and certificates.
The Metasettings screen is not ment to be attacked. Currently there are three settings you can change to your liking:
1) IP, change this field to the IP of your DIBAServer to make the app functional.
2) Difficulty, as mentioned above, change to see if you could break the communication even on different levels. Note that Difficulty REALLY_HARD has no known weakness.
3) Timeout, the amount of milliseconds till the connection times out.
